Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 03:35PM Indomitable1 wrote: OK-so let me ask another way....Has anyone else ever had to stop chemo temporarily for more than a week or so for any reason?  It's been almost 6 weeks on a q3 week regimen...and will most likely be a total of at least 8 prior to my next treatment. I can't seem to find any research re: breaks in chemo so I'd like to hear from anyone with a similar experience to see how it was handled.
Posts.Title: Interrupted Chemo Indomitable1 Indomitable1

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 04:16PM Indomitable1 wrote: I had BLMas yesterday and was released last night. So far so good at home. 3 drains. I guess I got the drive by/drive thru....but am glad to be in the comfort of my own home. Wasn't rushed out of the Recovery Room....as a matter of fact, I had an angel for a nurse, Maggie.  But, working in the medical profession, I have to say, I hate being an inpt so asked to be done on an outpt basis if there were no complications. DH is being wonderfully supportive-as are dear kids and friends (meals planned for next few days.)
Posts.Title: How long was your Hosp stay for BLMas LynnVA NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 11:21AM - edited Oct 31, 2009 11:21AM by Indomitable1 Thanks for the info sjack. Stephanie was an inspiration and a witness as she ran this race with faith knowing that God is able. May He continue to strengthen and comfort her family as she is delivered from pain and strife into eternal life. Although tears I shed, I know that she has graduated from BC survivor to an Overcomer. Gainesville, FL
Posts.Title: Stephanie is an Angel 2timer Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 10:42AM Indomitable1 wrote: Hello Ladies! Long time no post so forgive the long post following. You can count me in the charred yet raw category. I developed no blisters but the charred (black, tight) areas of skin just opened. My supraclavicular nodes were included in my regular tx sites and turning my neck on Friday apparently caused the initial split in the skin. Oh well. Two more boost or reductions to go. Thank God that area is still intact. And I forgot who asked but I've had the bolus used every other treatment. The cold gel pad reportedly increases the dose to the area of interest. My wonderful tech was kind enuff to allow me in the dressing area 1 patient prior to my actual tx so I could sit on the bolus while waiting for my turn up at bat. It worked wonders! Of course, I had to ask but he obliged. BTW, I noticed you're triple neg. too. Perhaps that's why we're getting it. Will pick up the silvadene script after tx today--if I last that long. Thank God I'm off today. And to someone else (still using chemobrain as my excuse for forgetting who posted what)- I love Flylady!!!!!!-especially when I follow my routines -even though I often skip the 15 min declutter. Sorry about the arimidex issue-can't help. I'm triple negative. u'll probably think i'm just paranoid but i sure do wish there was something else i could take. Will pick up the Foods that fight Cancer book as I have already read the AntiCancer book. Rad Onc said I could resume taking my antioxidants the day after tx. Congrats to those who've finished before, Hang in there to those still undergoing tx. And thanks to all!
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2009 10:04PM Indomitable1 wrote: Hee Hee Hee....Mimi/Renee-I usually start work at 7 am and was hoping to do my rads after work....was told several months ago before my chemo that the center would be open until 7 pm.....now the last appt is at 3:45! So, I'm leaving work early. Sorrry to hear that I'm not the only one with scheduling issues. I'm on Day 3. My PA told me to use Vit E mixed with aloe....tech told me today NO Vit E oil or oil of any kind. Will have to look up the calendula and Remedy. I was told I could use the mineral/salt deodorants on the side getting rads, too. I'm about to go back and review ALL the posts but is there anything else (HUGE) that I should be aware avoid or try? Thanks in advance.
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2009 08:08PM Indomitable1 wrote: Yes, it is all a bit overwhelming. I know, I know.... it's all downhill from here- having completed the chemo.  But, I am tired. Don't really think that it's the rads as I've only completed one week. I, too, have a new discomfort in the underarm area but think it is related to the positioning. I don't have the "custom mold" so it takes about 10 mins to "get things lined up." More uncomfortable than the underarm is the backache (between the scapulae) I develop while lying on the table. I've been taking an occasional tylenol vs. ibuprofen. I would have liked to have completed rads before  the New Year, too but had delay after delay. At least I've finally started. Good luck Pill in whatever you decide. Will try to get the Remedy. Thanks for the info.
Posts.Title: December 2009 Rads Group Linda_NJ BonnieSF

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 11:17PM Indomitable1 wrote: Today, I had problems with my drains and needed my husband to help change the dressing. It finally hit me. I was on "get it off/fight this" mode since initial dx. I knew what I had to do. Didn't doubt the decision once. They served their purpose. Never really particuarly proud of them but they did have their positives....I can live without them but the thought of my husband seeing the still healing incisional scars and drains just threw me for a loop today. I'd been handling this fairly well. Sorta felt like a set back today (increased pain(back), increased drainage, And no boobs)--but then I realized that it's the realization that this is just the beginning that has me thrown. Sorry, we're here for the reasons that we're here, but thankful that we've got each other. Thanks TCGGal for venting and allowing us to do the same. God Bless each of us in this journey. Faithandprayers, I pray that your results were favorable and that you have focal/local disease with receptor positivity! Tara-hang in there. You'll find lots of great info and support here.
Posts.Title: OMG-it hit me today-HARD! TCGGal faithandprayers

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 10:57PM Indomitable1 wrote: OncRN- Glad things went so well for you. I can't imagine what you must have expected considering your hx of working in the field. And sorry, you know that medical professionals tend to make the worst patients. Had terrible mid-back pain tonight. Don't know if I'm overdoing it or not. Resumed a DVD walking program on POD 2 (but only did a mile today). Skipped my mid-day nap, went riding with my husband...Took Lortab tonight. Have only used it 3x since surgery. Still with significant drainage, arm numbness and occasional shooting pains in the posterior arm. LynnVA- it's not as bad as you expect...but of course it's not easy. These discussion boards really help with expectations and normalizing your experience. You'll do well. I'm keeping you in my prayers.  Your prayers for me are much appreciated. Keep positive, you've caught it early. You're being proactive. I have my moments..but seeing that we can help each other is so powerful. I see my surgeon in follow up tomorrow. Am anticipating another week of drains at least. Don't won't to go back to work (in a hopsital) with them in if at all possible.  I opted for delayed recon as I will be undergoing rad tx, too.
Posts.Title: How long was your Hosp stay for BLMas LynnVA NancyD

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 01:08PM Indomitable1 wrote: cs34-thanks for asking-I'm feeling better than I anticipated...but... i too have the numbness and shooting pain in the arm and axillary region on the right side. I had SNB bilaterally but the left is much better. I think she removed more LN on the right side. Of course, I'm sore and numb and achy but so glad to be here. So sorry to hear about your drains still being in place....And you're right, when we can't stay positive, His grace is sufficient. Let's not beat ourselves up about having REAL feelings, let's just not be ruled by them.  I was told to take off for 2 weeks only-but I didn't have any reconstrux started. I'm a wimp.....one thing at a time... Big Apple-thanks for describing how to strip/milk the tubes...I guess I must have missed that in our d/c instructions.  I also obviously didn't think about the cosmesis of trying to return to work with no reconst...and highly doubt I'll have the drains out in 2 weeks. Heard my BS won't  approve a prosthetic bra even if I'm healed at 4 weeks. Hope you get the info you're looking for re: the implants. Gotta get creative!
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 12:12AM Indomitable1 wrote: Unique-I had axillary cord syndrome. (I[m completing chemo, haven't yet gotten to rads!) Was very tender and sore along the cords. My PT was able to work them out quite well. Unfortunately, I picked up a toddler at church (half of a set of crying twins. I forgot!) and subsequently developed swelling/lymphedema in the arm. So, be sure to do all the preventive measures recommended. (I[m completing chemo, haven't yet gotten to rads!) Please be careful, diligent and take care.
